Empirical Mapping of Technology Language Evolution

When concepts evolve faster than institutions can standardize them, coordination failures compound. Observable Compute Foundation provides the first systematic observatory tracking where technology terminology actually clusters versus where institutions say it should.

Explore the Lexicon Read Latest Report

What We Track

Legal-Technical Alignment

Systematic documentation of technical accuracy in technology regulation, preventing compounding errors in binding law.

Browse Critical Gaps →

Terminology Evolution

Empirical tracking of AI concept emergence, definition shifts, and adoption velocity across research, industry, government, and public domains.

View Emerging Concepts →

Conceptual Clustering

Where concepts actually cluster through co-occurrence analysis versus imposed taxonomies. Revealing unexpected conceptual neighborhoods.

Explore Clusters →

Latest Quarterly Report

Latest Report

State of AI Systems: Q1 2026

Published April 1, 2026

This inaugural report documents 30+ critical legal-technical misalignments, tracks emergence of 50+ new concepts, and provides the first empirical mapping of AI terminology clustering patterns.

  • Critical Gap: California SB 1047 "algorithmic decision system" definition captures Excel spreadsheets
  • Emerging Concept: "Agentic AI" shows 400% quarterly usage increase with 7 competing definitions
  • Clustering Pattern: "Reasoning" + "Chain-of-thought" correlation 0.89, unexpectedly clusters with "Error correction" (0.76)
Read Full Report View All Reports

Why Systematic Terminology Tracking Matters

Legal Definitions Calcify

Once encoded in statute or case law, technical inaccuracies persist for decades. A single imprecise definition in binding law creates compounding coordination failures.

Tech Evolves Faster Than Standardization

Between coining and codification, concepts drift. Nobody systematically tracks this gap. We do.

Translation Breaks Across Domains

Researchers, lawyers, policymakers, and the public use different definitions for the same terms. We map where and why translation fails.
